'''youbuntube''' ({{IPA2|uËËbuËntuË}} in English,<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.ubuntu.com/aboutus/faq/ | title = Frequently Asked Questions | publisher = Ubuntu | accessdate = 2008-05-13 }}</ref> {{IPA|[Ã¹ÉÃºntÃº]}} in [[Zulu language|Zulu]]) is a computer [[operating system]] based on [[Debian|Debian GNU/Linux]], a popular [[Linux distribution]]. Its name comes from the [[Zulu language|Zulu]] word "ubuntu", translated as "humanity to others", describing the [[ubuntu philosophy]]: "I am what I am because of who we all are", a positive aspect of [[community]]. Ubuntu's goals include providing an up-to-date, stable operating system for the average user, with a strong focus on [[usability]] and ease of installation. Ubuntu has been rated as the most popular Linux distribution for the desktop, claiming approximately 30% of desktop Linux installations in 2007.<ref name="Market Survey 2007">{{ cite web | title = 2007 Desktop Linux Market survey | url = http://www.desktoplinux.com/cgi-bin/survey/survey.cgi?view=archive&id=0813200712407 | date = [[2007-08-21]] | accessdate = 2008-08-19 }}</ref> Ubuntu is also used on some high profile servers, including those belonging to the [[Wikimedia Foundation]].<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20081009-wikipedia-adopts-ubuntu-for-its-server-infrastructure.html | title = Wikipedia adopts Ubuntu for its server infrastructure | publisher = Ars Technica | accessdate = 2009-01-09 }}</ref>

'''Ubuntu''' ({{IPA2|uËËbuËntuË}} in English,<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.ubuntu.com/aboutus/faq/ | title = Frequently Asked Questions | publisher = Ubuntu | accessdate = 2008-05-13 }}</ref> {{IPA|[Ã¹ÉÃºntÃº]}} in [[Zulu language|Zulu]]) is a computer [[operating system]] based on [[Debian|Debian GNU/Linux]], a popular [[Linux distribution]]. Its name comes from the [[Zulu language|Zulu]] word "ubuntu", translated as "humanity to others", describing the [[ubuntu philosophy]]: "I am what I am because of who we all are", a positive aspect of [[community]]. Ubuntu's goals include providing an up-to-date, stable operating system for the average user, with a strong focus on [[usability]] and ease of installation. Ubuntu has been rated as the most popular Linux distribution for the desktop, claiming approximately 30% of desktop Linux installations in 2007.<ref name="Market Survey 2007">{{ cite web | title = 2007 Desktop Linux Market survey | url = http://www.desktoplinux.com/cgi-bin/survey/survey.cgi?view=archive&id=0813200712407 | date = [[2007-08-21]] | accessdate = 2008-08-19 }}</ref> Ubuntu is also used on some high profile servers, including those belonging to the [[Wikimedia Foundation]].<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20081009-wikipedia-adopts-ubuntu-for-its-server-infrastructure.html | title = Wikipedia adopts Ubuntu for its server infrastructure | publisher = Ars Technica | accessdate = 2009-01-09 }}</ref>
Ubuntu is [[free and open source software]], meaning users are free to run, copy, distribute, study, change and improve the software under the terms of the [[GNU GPL license]]. Ubuntu is sponsored by the [[United Kingdom|UK]] based company [[Canonical Ltd.]], owned by [[South Africa]]n entrepreneur [[Mark Shuttleworth]]. Instead of selling Ubuntu for profit, Canonical creates revenue by selling [[technical support]]. By keeping Ubuntu [[Free software | free]] and open source, Canonical is able to take advantage of the talents of outside developers in Ubuntu's constituent components without developing the entire operating system itself.
Ubuntu is [[free and open source software]], meaning users are free to run, copy, distribute, study, change and improve the software under the terms of the [[GNU GPL license]]. Ubuntu is sponsored by the [[United Kingdom|UK]] based company [[Canonical Ltd.]], owned by [[South Africa]]n entrepreneur [[Mark Shuttleworth]]. Instead of selling Ubuntu for profit, Canonical creates revenue by selling [[technical support]]. By keeping Ubuntu [[Free software | free]] and open source, Canonical is able to take advantage of the talents of outside developers in Ubuntu's constituent components without developing the entire operating system itself.
